contentrichtext.text: During [[World War II]], '''Operation Gaff''' was a six-man patrol of [[Special Air Service]] [[British Commandos|commandos]], who parachuted into [[Nazi]]-occupied France on 18 July 1944, with the aim of killing or kidnapping Field Marshal [[Erwin Rommel]].<ref>{{cite book |title=Discovering the Rommel Murder: The Life and Death of the Desert Fox |last=Marshall |first=Charles F. |year=2002 |authorlink= Charles F. Marshall|publisher=Stackpole Books |isbn=0-8117-2472-7 |page=122 |isbn=978-0-8117-2472-2 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Bodyguard of lies, Volume 2 |last=Brown |first=Anthony Cave |authorlink=Anthony Cave Brown |year=1975 |publisher=[[Harper & Row]] |isbn=978-0-06-010551-8 |page=717 }}</ref> From March 1943, Allied Intelligence had been undertaking research on the whereabouts, bases and travel arrangements of Field Marshal Rommel. Part of the research asked the question of how easy it would be to kill Rommel. After [[D-Day]], the Allies were meeting fierce resistance, marshalled by Rommel with Hitler's orders to stand firm at all costs. With losses mounting, Field Marshal Montgomery agreed with a plan to take Rommel out of the battle plan.<ref name="DarMis">William B. Breuer, ''Daring missions of World War II'', pp.131-133, John Wiley & Sons, 2002 ISBN 0471150878.</ref> After SAS Lieutenant-Colonel William Fraser was told the location of Rommel's headquarters, a chateau home of the Dukes de [[Duc de La Rochefoucauld|La Rochefoucauld]] in the village of [[La Roche-Guyon]], Brigadier R.W. McLeod assigned six specially-trained assassins led by French SAS Captain [[Raymond Couraud|Jack William Raymond Lee]].<ref>[http://www.ww2awards.com/person/42850 "Couraud, Raymond"], World War 2.com. Retrieved and [http://www.webcitation.org/67vBRPbi3 archived] 25 May 2012.</ref> On July 18, Lee and his team parachuted into [[Orléans]]; they found that Rommel had been severely injured the previous day after his staff car had been overturned in an attack by RAF [[Hawker Typhoon]]s and replaced by [[Günther von Kluge]].<ref name="DarMis"/> With their plan redundant, they moved toward advancing [[US Army]] lines on foot, while ambushing trains and attacking German units along their route. They reached safety on 12 August.<ref>[http://association-sas.chez-alice.fr/PgeLEE&F.htm "Le Captain Lee-Couraud & le 'French Squadron' du DU 2nd S.A.S Regiment"], ''Association SAS'', retrieved and [http://www.webcitation.org/67vBkXSRi archived] 25 May 2012 (in French).</ref> ==See also== *[[Operation Flipper]], an earlier attempt to kill Rommel in North Africa. ==References== {{reflist}} {{British Commando raids of the Second World War}} [[Category:Conflicts in 1944]] [[Category:World War II British Commando raids|G]] [[Category:Special Air Service|Gaff]] [[Category:1944 in France]] {{World-War-II-stub}}
